top_categories.workout_context: At 124 miles, The Gralloch punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
The Gralloch’s scottish highlands gravel (75%), singletrack/dirt (25%) demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Racing The Gralloch isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
The Gralloch rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at The Gralloch when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Every session at The Gralloch intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of The Gralloch. Make this intensity feel like home.
At 124 miles, The Gralloch rewards a massive aerobic engine. This volume work builds the fat-oxidation capacity that keeps you moving when glycogen runs low.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at The Gralloch — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
The Gralloch’s 11,483ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
The Gralloch’s scottish highlands—remote technical terrain and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at The Gralloch — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on scottish highlands—remote technical terrain.

race_overlay.heat: September in Scottish Highlands, Scotland — September: 8-18°C, 40% rain chance, autumn conditions, hypothermia risk. Begin heat acclimatization 10–14 days before The Gralloch — 20–30min sauna sessions or midday rides in full kit. Pre-load sodium 48 hours out. Target 500–750ml/hr with electrolytes on race day.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for The Gralloch’s 124 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at The Gralloch demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride scottish highlands—remote technical terrain at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: scottish highlands gravel (75%), singletrack/dirt (25%), remote terrain. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 124 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, Gravel Specific, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 124 miles of scottish highlands—remote technical terrain in Scottish Highlands, Scotland.
